title: Canberra's energy cash deters investors
text:
The energy industry has warned ongoing intervention will deter investment as the government poured another $1 billion into the market and the Nationals said a feasibility study into a coal-fired power station in Queensland, underwritten by taxpayers, should begin within months.

With tensions simmering between the Nationals and the Liberals over coal, Nationals leader Michael McCormack said on Wednesday that the study, promised by Scott Morrison before the election to buy peace in the Coalition, will begin "probably early in the New Year".

Mr McCormack gave the assurance after a pledge by Mr Morrison to invest $1 billion to underwrite clean energy investments sparked fresh calls in the Nationals for coal to be given similar treatment.

The pledge also caused the Australian Energy Council to warn that the more the government became involved, the more it would deter private investment.

"With the energy sector likely to need hundreds of billions in new utility-scale generation assets over the next 30 years, the task can only be met by a functioning market that encourages private capital, rather than requiring government to continue to intervene and pick winners,'' a spokesman said.

Under its policy to underwrite energy investment to guarantee supply, Mr Morrison and Energy Minister Angus Taylor announced the $1 billion injection for the Clean Energy Finance Corporation, which is a loan facility set up by Labor and which the Coalition originally tried to abolish.
description: The energy industry has warned ongoing intervention will deter investment as the government poured another $1 billion into the market and pays for a coal power feasibility study.
